root.geography: all Formosan languages are spoken on Taiwan
root.publications: Dyen, Isidore. 1971. The Austronesian Languages of Formosa, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, vol. 8, 168-199. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Node not name by the author. “There is now evidence that points to the grouping of Tsouic with Paiwanic against Atayalic with Kavalan's position somewhat ambiguous, but generally favoring Paiwanic against Atayalic. To this extent quantitative evidence suggests two main groups on Formosa” (Dyen 1971:175).
child.publications: Dyen, Isidore. 1971. The Austronesian Languages of Formosa, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, vol. 8, 168-199. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Dyen, Isidore. 1971. The Austronesian Languages of Formosa, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, vol. 8, 168-199. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.geography: formerly spoken across the northern end of the island; reported as occurring in one village in the Kavalan area

child.pub-comments: “There are three languages which in 1930 were used at home by speakers who elsewhere used Taiwanese: [Kavalan, Pazeh, and Thao]” (Dyen 1971:171).
child.geography: spoken near Lake Suisha in the center of the island
child.publications: Dyen, Isidore. 1971. The Austronesian Languages of Formosa, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, vol. 8, 168-199. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.geography: spoken on the eastern coastal plain from Sincheng to south of Taitung (Pinan)

child.pub-comments: “There are three languages which in 1930 were used at home by speakers who elsewhere used Taiwanese: [Kavalan, Pazeh, and Thao]” (Dyen 1971:171).
child.geography: spoken near the west coast just north of 24° N. latitude
child.publications: Dyen, Isidore. 1971. The Austronesian Languages of Formosa, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, vol. 8, 168-199. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Dyen mentions that Taokas might be a dialect of Hoanya (1971:171).

child.pub-comments: “The closer relation between the Atayalic languages (Atayal, Seediq) and between the Tsouic languages (Tsou, Saaroa, and Kanakanabu) is evidenced by the high percentages that these sets of languages respectively share with their co-members” (Dyen 1971:174).
child.publications: Dyen, Isidore. 1971. The Austronesian Languages of Formosa, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, vol. 8, 168-199. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.geography: spoken in the west central mountains southeast of Kagi around Mt.Ali.

child.pub-comments: “There are three languages which in 1930 were used at home by speakers who elsewhere used Taiwanese: [Kavalan, Pazeh, and Thao]” (Dyen 1971:171). “There is now evidence that points to the grouping of Tsouic with Paiwanic against Atayalic with Kavalan's position somewhat ambiguous, but generally favoring Paiwanic against Atayalic. To this extent quantitative evidence suggests two main groups on Formosa” (Dyen 1971:175).
child.geography: spoken in the northeast of the island
child.publications: Dyen, Isidore. 1971. The Austronesian Languages of Formosa, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, vol. 8, 168-199. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Speakers: 49,406. “The closer relation between the Atayalic languages (Atayal, Seediq) and between the Tsouic languages (Tsou, Saaroa, and Kanakanabu) is evidenced by the high percentages that these sets of languages respectively share with their co-members” (Dyen 1971:174).
